This dazzling drone footage captures a lone mountain climber scaling Britain’s highest peak – and the stunning scenes were filmed by the man himself.
Rob Johnson recorded high-definition video of his solo climb on Ben Nevis with a camera attached to a remote-control drone.
The device buzzed around the famous mountain and captured amazing scenes that look like they were shot by a film crew on a helicopter.

This drone footage captures a lone climber scaling Britain’s highest peak – and the stunning scenes were filmed by the man himself
Rob Johnson, from North Wales, recorded HD video of his solo climb on Ben Nevis with a camera attached to a remote-control drone
Rob’s four-minute video offers a fascinating and rare view of Ben Nevis, especially for those who have never scaled the 4,409ft peak
The device buzzed around the famous mountain and captured amazing scenes that look like they were shot by a film crew on a helicopter
The experienced climber makes it look easy as he trudges through untouched snow while controlling the drone flying overhead
Rob’s four-minute video offers a fascinating and rare view of Ben Nevis, especially for those who have never scaled the 4,409ft peak in the Scottish Highlands.

Rob, founder of an aerial photography and filming company called Filmuphigh.com, based in North Wales, made his ascent on Ben Nevis’ north face.
He wrote on his YouTube page: ‘I climbed Ledge Route, a grade 2 winter mountaineering route, and filmed myself as I climbed.
Rob, founder of an aerial photography and filming company, based in North Wales, made his ascent on Ben Nevis’ north face
It was a race against time for Rob, who tried to scale the mountain as fast as he could before his four batteries faded in the cold
The climb provided a challenge to Rob, who had to focus on his steps while composing the shots to get the footage he wanted
‘This project took four batteries and I was racing to climb faster than the batteries faded, whilst composing the shots and trying to get the footage I wanted.
‘It’s pretty difficult doing it this way, the ultimate mountain selfie perhaps.
‘It’s definitely easier to compose the shots when filming other people, but I enjoyed the challenge. It was a stunning day.’
The ledge route takes about eight hours to complete, with climbers covering a distance of eight miles and an ascent of 4,000ft.
